subtitleNullable: E-paint coating process including degradation progressions for multiple filters
descriptionNullable:
### Backgroud

Here is an industry case study from an electrophoresis painting plant where we recently deployed an IIoT system.  

There are two related datasets:

| Name |  Original sample rate | Covered time period | Unified sample rate |
| --- |  --- | --- |  --- |
| manual inspection records | every 8 hours per sample| 7 years| every 30 minutes per sample (up-sampled) |
| IIoT sensor readings | every 10 seconds per sample| 15 days| every 30 minutes per sample (down-sampled) |

This dataset repository is shared for:

1. develop, test and apply advanced data analytics methods (e.g. Deep Learning) for manufacturing problems 
2. let more people understand better the problems of manufacturing production processes (e.g. maintenance scheduling, continue processing).

### Challenges

There are some common challenges in real-world manufacturing datasets: The existing datasets are not designed for data analytics, and always with quality and quantity problems. 

In this case, the data collected from the new installed IIoT system is high resolution but only 15-days measurement periods have not collected sufficient incident events such as equipment failures or maintenance activities. The manual inspection records dataset has covered a long period but the quality is low because the original dataset is measured a maximum of 3 times per day and not including weekends and holidays, then upsampled from 3 samples per day to every 30 minutes. 

If target to use Deep Learning method to predict process conditions, neither of these datasets can train the model well individually.  If you only have limited resources (e.g. project need to be completed in one week, no additional time to collect new sensor readings from the IIoT system), how would you train a machine learning model to predict process conditions with these given datasets?

### Content

In problem set addressed in this dataset, constitutes an electrophoresis painting plant that was built 20 years ago. Electrophoresis painting is characterised as a continuous manufacturing process as illustrated in Fig.


![Related electrophoresis painting process and installed sensors][id]

[id]: https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-user-content/o/inbox%2F3149056%2F93948592cefc955278021fd441fc0c09%2FE-painting%20system.png?generation=1600858850332467&alt=media =600x600

The sensor readings (also called features) have been normalised into range (0,1) to avoid sensitive information from the business while maintaining usability for data analysis. Please note all pressure sensors are normalised together rather than normalised by each individual sensor readings.

Note: feature 'TP2' has not been measured by manual inspection. It's available after we installed the IIoT system.

### Acknowledgements

The authors would like to firstly acknowledge our industry partner Tinsley Bridge Limited for providing the case study and their process data for the research projects.

Related research projects have received funding from Research England’s Connecting Capability Fund award CCF18-7157 – Promoting the Internet of Things via Collaboration between HEIs and Industry (Pitch-In);  Royal Academy of Engineering under the Research Chairs and Senior Research Fellowships scheme; Royal Academy of Engineering Regional Engagement Award.

Related research projects introduction:

- [Pitch-In project: Internet of Things (IoT) approach for predictive maintenance: a manufacturing case study](https://pitch-in.ac.uk/projects/predictive-maintenance/)
- [Pitch-In project: Distributed learning with IoT for quality control in manufacturing](https://pitch-in.ac.uk/projects/distributed-learning-with-iot-for-quality-control-in-manufacturing/)

Background and business context of our project: 

- [Pitch-In interview: Developing an automated industry IoT solution for predictive maintenance](https://pitch-in.ac.uk/developing-an-automated-industry-iot-solution-for-predictive-maintenance/)

### Inspiration

Process condition prediction is the initial step of Predictive Maintenance

Time-series forecasting methods can be applied for the manufacturing process data, such as LSTM

Transfer Learning may help to address the challenges in this case
title: E-coating ultrafiltration maintenance dataset
subtitle: E-paint coating process including degradation progressions for multiple filters
